Working with ColorMaps¶

imwrite¶

Provides a wrapper to imwrite() for use with a given :ocv:class`ColorMap`.

C++: void imwrite(const string& filename, InputArray img, const colormap::ColorMap& cm, const vector<int>& params=vector<int>())¶

This makes applying a colormap::ColorMap and storing the result as easy as writing:

imwrite("image.png", img, colormap::Jet());

See imwrite() for the list of supported formats and flags description.

imshow¶

Provides a wrapper to imshow() for use with a given :ocv:class`ColorMap`.

C++: void imshow(const string& winname, InputArray img, const colormap::ColorMap& cm)¶

This makes applying a colormap::ColorMap and storing the result as easy as writing:

imwshow("image", img, colormap::Jet());

See imshow() for the list of supported formats and flags description.

ColorMap¶

class colormap::ColorMap¶

It’s a fact, that human perception isn’t built for observing fine changes in grayscale images. Human sensors (eyes and stuff) are more sensitive to observing changes between colors, so you often need to recolor your grayscale images to get a clue about them. colormap::ColorMap is the base class for colormaps in OpenCV. The following colormaps are included in libfacerec and equivalent to their GNU Octave/MATLAB counterparts:

Class Scale
colormap::Autumn
colormap::Bone
colormap::Cool
colormap::Hot
colormap::HSV
colormap::Jet
colormap::MKPJ1
colormap::MKPJ2
colormap::Ocean
colormap::Pink
colormap::Rainbow
colormap::Spring
colormap::Summer
colormap::Winter

Applying the Jet colormap on a Matrix is then as easy as writing:

colormap::Jet jet; // default: 256-levels
Mat colored = jet(img);

There’s also a the wrapper function for imshow:

imwshow("image", img, colormap::Jet());

And a wrapper to imwrite:

imwrite("image.png", img, colormap::Jet());
